questions.title: Passage I
questions.article: Students conducted an experiment to see how jumping on a merry-go-round affects how fast it spins. In each case an empty spinning merry-go-round was approached by a student who ran in the direction shown in Figure 1 and then jumped on the edge. Several trials, each consisting of three runs, were performed using students of different masses running at different speeds, and different initial spin rates for the merry-go-round, given in revolutions per minute (rpm). The results are shown in Table 1.
questions.question: 1. In the Trial 5, as the student's speed increased, the final spin rate:

choices.A: decreased only.
choices.B: increased only.
choices.C: increased, then decreased.
choices.D: remained the same.

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article: Students conducted an experiment to see how jumping on a merry-go-round affects how fast it spins. In each case an empty spinning merry-go-round was approached by a student who ran in the direction shown in Figure 1 and then jumped on the edge. Several trials, each consisting of three runs, were performed using students of different masses running at different speeds, and different initial spin rates for the merry-go-round, given in revolutions per minute (rpm). The results are shown in Table 1.
questions.question: 2. In Trial 1, the factor that most directly determined if the final spin rate was greater than the initial spin rate was:

choices.A: gravity.
choices.B: the mass of the student.
choices.C: the speed of the student.
choices.D: the weight of the student.

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article: Students conducted an experiment to see how jumping on a merry-go-round affects how fast it spins. In each case an empty spinning merry-go-round was approached by a student who ran in the direction shown in Figure 1 and then jumped on the edge. Several trials, each consisting of three runs, were performed using students of different masses running at different speeds, and different initial spin rates for the merry-go-round, given in revolutions per minute (rpm). The results are shown in Table 1.
questions.question: 3. Suppose that in a fourth run in Trial 4, a student had jumped on the merry-go-round and the final spin rate was 13.30 rpm. The student's mass would most likely have been:

choices.A: 30 kg.
choices.B: 40 kg.
choices.C: 50 kg.
choices.D: 60 kg.

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article: Students conducted an experiment to see how jumping on a merry-go-round affects how fast it spins. In each case an empty spinning merry-go-round was approached by a student who ran in the direction shown in Figure 1 and then jumped on the edge. Several trials, each consisting of three runs, were performed using students of different masses running at different speeds, and different initial spin rates for the merry-go-round, given in revolutions per minute (rpm). The results are shown in Table 1.
questions.question: 4. Which of the following trials disproved the hypothesis that the final spin rate will always increase as the mass of the student increases?

choices.A: Trial 4
choices.B: Trial 5
choices.C: Trial 6
choices.D: Trial 8

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article: Students conducted an experiment to see how jumping on a merry-go-round affects how fast it spins. In each case an empty spinning merry-go-round was approached by a student who ran in the direction shown in Figure 1 and then jumped on the edge. Several trials, each consisting of three runs, were performed using students of different masses running at different speeds, and different initial spin rates for the merry-go-round, given in revolutions per minute (rpm). The results are shown in Table 1.
questions.question: 5. If a student runs at a certain speed called the critical speed, the final spin rate of the merry-go-round will equal the initial spin rate regardless of the student's mass. For an initial spin rate of 10 rpm, the critical speed is:

choices.A: 1.36 m/sec.
choices.B: 1.50 m/sec.
choices.C: 2.00 m/sec.
choices.D: 3.00 m/sec.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Disinfection is a process in which harmful bacteria and viruses are destroyed. Two scientists present their opinions on disinfection of water by chlorine.

Scientist 1

Chlorine (Cl2) should not be used to disinfect public water supplies. Water supplies contain bacteria and viruses as well as natural organic matter. Organic by-products are formed when chemical reactions between Cl2 and natural organic matter occur. These by-products should not be in public water systems because they are hazardous and can be toxic to humans.

Any Cl2 left in water after disinfection is then consumed by the public. The excess Cl2 can react with the components of saliva, stomach fluid, and food, thus forming new by-products which could also be toxic.

There are alternatives to Cl2 for the disinfection of drinking water. Chlorine dioxide and chloramine are milder forms of chlorine that could be used to disinfect water. Ozone is another possible disinfectant. The use of ultraviolet (UV) radiation to disinfect water has also been found to kill viruses more effectively than Cl2.

Scientist 2

Chlorine should be used to disinfect public water supplies. Chlorine can, in many cases, be more effective than other methods of disinfection. Chloramine will effectively kill bacteria, but is much less effective than Cl2 in destroying viruses. UV radiation can inactivate bacteria and viruses, but in some cases the regrowth of bacteria has been found.

There is concern that organic by-products are formed by the reaction of Cl2 with natural organic matter in the water. However, there are ways to remove these by-products. One is by first removing the natural organic matter before it reacts with the Cl2. This is accomplished by an extra treatment step such as filtering the water beforet he addition of Cl2. Subsequent addition of sodium sulfite to the Cl2-treated water will remove or destroy any excess by-products.

In addition to killing bacteria and viruses, Cl2 will also react with some undesirable pesticides that may be present in the water already. These reactions can cause the amount of pesticides in the water to decrease.
questions.question: 6. Which of the following considerations in regard to water disinfection does NEITHER scientist discuss?

choices.A: The cost of Cl2 disinfection versus alternative disinfection processes
choices.B: The effectiveness of Cl2 disinfection versus alternative disinfection processes
choices.C: The hazards of Cl2 disinfection versus alternative disinfection processes
choices.D: The by-products of Cl2 disinfection versus alternative disinfection processes

questions.question: 7. Which of the following statements would support Scientist 1's opinion concerning the formation of hazardous substances by Cl2? Hazardous substances are:

choices.A: formed when Cl2 is mixed with saliva.
choices.B: formed when Cl2 is mixed with ozone.
choices.C: not formed when Cl2 is mixed with food.
choices.D: not formed when Cl2 is mixed with saliva.

questions.question: 8. The graphs below show what may happen to the amount of aldicarb (a common pesticide) in water when increasing amounts of Cl2 are added. Which of the following graphs best supports the statement made by Scientist 2 about pesticides?

questions.question: 9. The main source of argument between the opinions of Scientists 1 and 2 is about:

choices.A: whether water should be disinfected.
choices.B: the presence of natural organic matter in water.
choices.C: whether to use Cl2 to disinfect water.
choices.D: the effectiveness of Cl2 in killing bacteria.

choices.A: they are not fomred when Cl2 is added to water.

choices.D: they can be controlled by additional water treatment.

questions.question: 11. Which of the following flow charts represents the water treatment scheme described by Scientist 2 ?

choices.A: Cl2 added to water            ↓Water filtered            ↓Sodium sulfite added to water
choices.B: Water filtered            ↓Cl2 added to water            ↓Sodium sulfite added to water
choices.C: Sodium sulfite added to water            ↓Cl2 added to water            ↓Water filtered
choices.D: Chloramine added to water             ↓Water filtered             ↓Cl2 added to water

questions.question: 12. According to Scientist 2, the type of water best suited to Cl2 disinfection would contain a:

choices.A: high concentration of organic by-products.
choices.B: low concentration of carbon dioxide.
choices.C: high concentration of natural organic matter.
choices.D: low concentration of natural organic matter.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
A metal string stretched between two fixed ends will vibrate and produce a sound when it is plucked, as illustrated in Figure 1.


To investigate how sounds are produced, a student used strings constructed of either steel, aluminum, or an unknown material. String of differing lengths, radii, and materials were stretched with various tensions between fixed ends. When plucked, each of these strings produced a sound of a specific fundamental frequency (pitch). The results appear in Table 1.
questions.question: 13. According to Table 1, as the radius of a string is doubled, the frequency is:

choices.A: halved.
choices.B: doubled.
choices.C: tripled.
choices.D: quadrupled.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:

To investigate how sounds are produced, a student used strings constructed of either steel, aluminum, or an unknown material. String of differing lengths, radii, and materials were stretched with various tensions between fixed ends. When plucked, each of these strings produced a sound of a specific fundamental frequency (pitch). The results appear in Table 1.
questions.question: 14. Which of the following was a result of the experiments and NOT one of the factors controlled as input for an experiment?

choices.A: Material
choices.B: Length
choices.C: Frequency
choices.D: Radius

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:

String of differing lengths, radii, and materials were stretched with various tensions between fixed ends. When plucked, each of these strings produced a sound of a specific fundamental frequency (pitch). The results appear in Table 1.
questions.question: 15. Based on Table 1, if the length of a string were decreased while the tension was kept constant, the frequency would be expected to:

choices.A: increase only.
choices.B: decrease only.
choices.C: decrease, then increase.
choices.D: remain the same.

String of differing lengths, radii, and materials were stretched with various tensions between fixed ends. When plucked, each of these strings produced a sound of a specific fundamental frequency (pitch). The results appear in Table 1.
questions.question: 16. A steel piano wire of radius 0.2 mm is subjected to a tension of 1,000 N. Based on Table 1, if the frequency needs to be 660 Hz, the length of the wire should be closest to which of the following values?

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
A metal string stretched between two fixed ends will vibrate and produce a sound when it is plucked, as illustrated in Figure 1.


To investigate how sounds are produced, a student used strings constructed of either steel, aluminum, or an unknown material. String of differing lengths, radii, and materials were stretched with various tensions between fixed ends. When plucked, each of these strings produced a sound of a specific fundamental frequency (pitch). The results appear in Table 1.
questions.question: 17. Based on Table 1, to produce the lowest frequency possible from a string of a given material, the string should be:

choices.A: short and under low tension, with a small radius.
choices.B: short and under low tension, with a large radius.
choices.C: long and under low tension, with a small radius.
choices.D: long and under low tension, with a large radius.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants convert light energy into chemical energy. The process is shown in the generalized reaction below.

To study photosynthesis in the plant Elodea, a scientist conducted three experiments using the apparatus shown in Figure 1 below. In each experiment, the cut end of a 5-inch length of Elodea was inserted into the opening of an inverted graduated cylinder in Beaker A. All tests were conducted using a 60-watt floodlamp in a room at constant temperature. The amount of oxygen (O2) produced in the graduated cylinder, in milliliters (mL), was used as an estimate of the photosynthetic activity. The results from all three experiments are reported in Table 1.


Experiment 1

In this experiment, the effect of light intensity was studied. The distance between the floodlamp and Beaker A was varied. In each test, the amount of O2 produced after 10 minutes was recorded.

Experiment 2

In this experiment, the effect of light duration was studied. The amount of O2 produced in the graduated cylinder after various durations of light exposure was recorded.

Experiment 3

In this experiment, the effect of light color was studied. Filters of different colors were placed between Beaker A and Beaker B. Only wavelengths of light the same color as each filter could pass through the filters.
questions.question: 18. Based on the results of all three experiments, one can generalize that photosynthesis is influenced by which of the factors listed below?            I. Light intensity           II. Light duration          III. Light color

choices.A: I only
choices.B: II only
choices.C: I and II only
choices.D: I, II, and III

Experiment 3

questions.question: 19. The purpose of the green filter in Experiment 3 was to:

choices.A: prevent all wavelengths of light from reaching the plants.
choices.B: restrict exposure of the plant to only green wave-lengths of light.
choices.C: restrict exposure of the plant to only blue and red wavelengths of light.
choices.D: filter out potentially damaging ultraviolet light that might harm the plant.

questions.question: 20. The researcher repeated Experiment 3 with Plant 8. Which of the following changes in the experimental procedure would result in less O2 being produced?

choices.A: Using no filter
choices.B: Using a 100-watt lamp
choices.C: Placing the Iamp 2 feet away
choices.D: Conducting the test for 15 minutes

questions.question: 21. Experiment 1 was repeated with a new Elodea under conditions identical to those used for Plant 1. The amount of O2 measured was 1.7 mL. Such a difference in results between repeated experiments using different plants is to be expected because:

choices.A: Plant 1 received light for a longer duration.
choices.B: the new plant received light at a higher intensity.
choices.C: of individual differences between plants in the number of leaves or leaf surface area.
choices.D: all factors that could influence the results were controlled.

questions.question: 22. Water temperature affects the photosynthetic activity of aquatic plants such as Elodea. Based on the information in the passage and in Figure 1, one would conclude that the temperature of the water in Beaker A was controlled in the experiments by:

choices.A: placing Beaker B between Beaker A and the floodlamp.
choices.B: placing colored filters between Beaker A and the floodlamp.
choices.C: varying the distance between the colored filters and the floodlamp.
choices.D: varying the amount of time that Beaker A was exposed to light.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants convert light energy into chemical energy. The process is shown in the generalized reaction below.

To study photosynthesis in the plant Elodea, a scientist conducted three experiments using the apparatus shown in Figure 1 below. In each experiment, the cut end of a 5-inch length of Elodea was inserted into the opening of an inverted graduated cylinder in Beaker A. All tests were conducted using a 60-watt floodlamp in a room at constant temperature. The amount of oxygen (O2) produced in the graduated cylinder, in milliliters (mL), was used as an estimate of the photosynthetic activity. The results from all three experiments are reported in Table 1.


Experiment 1

In this experiment, the effect of light intensity was studied. The distance between the floodlamp and Beaker A was varied. In each test, the amount of O2 produced after 10 minutes was recorded.

Experiment 2

In this experiment, the effect of light duration was studied. The amount of O2 produced in the graduated cylinder after various durations of light exposure was recorded.

Experiment 3

In this experiment, the effect of light color was studied. Filters of different colors were placed between Beaker A and Beaker B. Only wavelengths of light the same color as each filter could pass through the filters.
questions.question: 23. Based on the results of all three experiments, under which of the following sets of experimental conditions would the LEAST amount of O2 be produced?

choices.A: Lamp at 6 inches for 10 minutes, no filter
choices.B: Lamp at 1 foot for 20 minutes, no filter
choices.C: Lamp at 2 feet for 10 minutes, no filter
choices.D: Lamp at 2 feet for 10 minutes, blue filter

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article: The mineral sets (groups of two or more minerals) in a rock can provide clues to the pressure and temperature conditions under which the rock was formed. The figure shows the pressure, in kilobars (kb), and temperature relationships of six minerals (A, B, C, D, E, and F). As temperature and/or pressure changes, one mineral may react to form another. A given mineral is present only along its respective line and in the field on one side of the line.
questions.question: 24. According to the figure, which of the statements below would be true of the formation conditions of a rock containing Minerals B, D, and F?          I. The temperature was above 250℃.         II. The pressure was above 4 kb.        III. The temperature was lower than that of a rock containing Minerals A, D, and F.

choices.A: I only
choices.B: II only
choices.C: III only
choices.D: I and II only

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article: The mineral sets (groups of two or more minerals) in a rock can provide clues to the pressure and temperature conditions under which the rock was formed. The figure shows the pressure, in kilobars (kb), and temperature relationships of six minerals (A, B, C, D, E, and F). As temperature and/or pressure changes, one mineral may react to form another. A given mineral is present only along its respective line and in the field on one side of the line.
questions.question: 25. According to the figure, at which of the following pressure-temperature conditions is the Mineral Set ABEF present?

choices.A: 300℃ and 4.5 kb
choices.B: 300℃ and 5.5 kb
choices.C: 350℃ and 2.5 kb
choices.D: 550℃ and 4.5 kb

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article: The mineral sets (groups of two or more minerals) in a rock can provide clues to the pressure and temperature conditions under which the rock was formed. The figure shows the pressure, in kilobars (kb), and temperature relationships of six minerals (A, B, C, D, E, and F). As temperature and/or pressure changes, one mineral may react to form another. A given mineral is present only along its respective line and in the field on one side of the line.
questions.question: 26. Laboratory experiments at the temperatures and pressures shown by the three solid circles near the bottom of the figure yielded Mineral Sets ACE, ACE, and ACF, left to right, respectively. The researcher concluded that any rock containing either Mineral A or C could only have formed at pressures below 1 kb. Is this conclusion supported by the figure?

choices.A: Yes, because A is present only at pressures below 1 kb.
choices.B: Yes, because C is present only at pressures below 1 kb.
choices.C: No, because A and C are also present at moderate to high pressures.
choices.D: No, because A and C are not present at any pressure below 6 kb.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article: The mineral sets (groups of two or more minerals) in a rock can provide clues to the pressure and temperature conditions under which the rock was formed. The figure shows the pressure, in kilobars (kb), and temperature relationships of six minerals (A, B, C, D, E, and F). As temperature and/or pressure changes, one mineral may react to form another. A given mineral is present only along its respective line and in the field on one side of the line.
questions.question: 27. Starting from Point Z on the figure (200°C and 2.5 kb), if the temperature were slowly raised by 200°C, and then the pressure slowly raised by 1 kb, the mineral set that is present would change from:

choices.A: ACE to ADE and then to ADF.
choices.B: ACE to ADE and then to BDE.
choices.C: ACE to ADE and then to BDF.
choices.D: ADE to ADF and then to BDF.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article: The mineral sets (groups of two or more minerals) in a rock can provide clues to the pressure and temperature conditions under which the rock was formed. The figure shows the pressure, in kilobars (kb), and temperature relationships of six minerals (A, B, C, D, E, and F). As temperature and/or pressure changes, one mineral may react to form another. A given mineral is present only along its respective line and in the field on one side of the line.
questions.question: 28. Which of the following best describes a pressure-temperature change that would cause Mineral C in a rock at Point Z on the figure to react to form Mineral D?

choices.A: Raising the temperature and keeping the pressure the same as at Point Z
choices.B: Lowering the temperature and keeping the pressure the same as at Point Z
choices.C: Keeping both temperature and pressure at the same levels as at Point Z
choices.D: Keeping the temperature the same as at Point Z and lowering the pressure

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
Lightning occurs when separate regions of positive and negative electrical charge develop in a cloud. Three experiments examined how these charges develop.

Experiment 1

Figure 1 shows the electrical charge (+ or -), altitude, and temperature, in degrees Celsius (°C), measured by several weather balloons as they rose through a thundercloud.


Experiment 2

Opposite charges may develop when H2O ice crystals and graupel (large ice and water particles) collide in a thundercloud. A chamber was filled with air at a known temperature (°C) and water content, in grams per cubic meter (g/m3). The charge, in coulombs (C), that formed on graupel falling through suspended H2O ice crystals and water droplets in the chamber was measured. The procedure was repeated for other temperatures and water contents. The results are shown in Figure 2.


Experiment 3

When water droplets containing dissolved ions freeze, opposite charges may develop between the newly formed ice crystals and the still unfrozen droplets. As the ice crystals and droplets separate in a cloud, charged regions form.

Solutions of four sodium (Na) salts, containing fluoride (F-) , chloride (Cl-), bromide (Br-), or iodide (I-) ions, were each made at six different concentrations, in moles per liter (moles/L). The solutions were slowly cooled until freezing began. The electrical potential (whether the droplets had a positive or negative charge with respect to the ice crystals) was measured in volts. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 29. According to the results of Experiment 3, the electrical potential that would develop between ice crystals and droplets of NaBr solution at a concentration of 10-3 moles/L would be approximately:

choices.A: +0.5 volts.
choices.B: +1.0 volts.
choices.C: +1.5 volts.
choices.D: +2.5 volts.

questions.article:

Experiment 3

Solutions of four sodium (Na) salts, containing fluoride (F-) , chloride (Cl-), bromide (Br-), or iodide (I-) ions, were each made at six different concentrations, in moles per liter (moles/L). The solutions were slowly cooled until freezing began. The electrical potential (whether the droplets had a positive or negative charge with respect to the ice crystals) was measured in volts. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 30. Which of the following best summarizes the purpose of Experiments 2 and 3?

choices.A: To find a process by which electrical charges could develop on particles commonly found in a thundercloud
choices.B: To find a method of measuring the concentration of sodium salts that exist in a thundercloud
choices.C: To discover why the temperatures in thunderclouds are so low
choices.D: To describe how wind causes the separation of charges in a thundercloud

questions.article:

Experiment 3

When water droplets containing dissolved ions freeze, opposite charges may develop between the newly formed ice crystals and the still unfrozen droplets. As the ice crystals and droplets separate in a cloud, charged regions form.

Solutions of four sodium (Na) salts, containing fluoride (F-) , chloride (Cl-), bromide (Br-), or iodide (I-) ions, were each made at six different concentrations, in moles per liter (moles/L). The solutions were slowly cooled until freezing began. The electrical potential (whether the droplets had a positive or negative charge with respect to the ice crystals) was measured in volts. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 31. Along with the experimental data, which of the following observations would support the hypothesis that electrical charges in a thundercloud may form by the collisions of H2O ice crystals?

choices.A: The natural concentration of sodium salts in the ice crystals in thunderclouds is well below 10-6 moles/L.
choices.B: The electric fields in clouds containing H2O ice crystals are much stronger than those of all-water clouds.
choices.C: The development of electrical charges decreases during the rapid vertical growth of the cloud.
choices.D: The temperature in some thunderclouds always stays above 0°C.

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:

Experiment 3

The solutions were slowly cooled until freezing began. The electrical potential (whether the droplets had a positive or negative charge with respect to the ice crystals) was measured in volts. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 32. If, instead of water, a solution of water and NaF had been used in the chamber of Experiment 2, according to the data provided, how would the charge that developed on the graupel have been different from that which developed using water?

choices.A: The graupel would have had a smaller positive charge at all water contents.
choices.B: The graupel would have had a negative charge at all water contents.
choices.C: The use of a NaF solution would not have affected the charge that developed on the graupel.
choices.D: This cannot be predicted from the given information.

questions.question: 33. If the results of Experiment 2 had been known before Experiment 1 was performed, which of the following modifications or changes in experimental design would have most improved Experiment 1?

choices.A: Measuring the electrical charge at Earth's surface
choices.B: Recording the distribution of electrical charges in another thundercloud
choices.C: Measuring the amount of precipitation that fell on Earth's surface
choices.D: Measuring the variation of the thundercloud's water content

questions.article:

Experiment 2

The procedure was repeated for other temperatures and water contents. The results are shown in Figure 2.


Experiment 3

When water droplets containing dissolved ions freeze, opposite charges may develop between the newly formed ice crystals and the still unfrozen droplets. As the ice crystals and droplets separate in a cloud, charged regions form.

Solutions of four sodium (Na) salts, containing fluoride (F-) , chloride (Cl-), bromide (Br-), or iodide (I-) ions, were each made at six different concentrations, in moles per liter (moles/L). The solutions were slowly cooled until freezing began. The electrical potential (whether the droplets had a positive or negative charge with respect to the ice crystals) was measured in volts. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 34. A scientist could best determine which ion (F-, Cl-, Br-, or I-) produced the greatest electrical potential in Experiment 3 by comparing the electrical potential that develops between ice crystals and droplets of:

choices.A: each of the sodium salt solutions at the same concentration.
choices.B: a single sodium salt solution at different concentrations.
choices.C: a single sodium salt solution at different temperatures.
choices.D: each of the sodium salt solutions at different collision rates.

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
A chemist studied nonpoisonous fluorocarbons, compounds composed of only carbon (C) atoms and fluorine（F) atoms, for potential use as blood substitutes. In order to be effective, the fluorocarbons had to be chemically stable at body temperature (37°C), able to transport oxygen (O2) from the lungs to the tissues, and able to transport carbon dioxide (CO2) from the tissues to the lungs. Chemical substitutes for blood are studied because they can be stored for long periods of time, do not carry diseases, and do not have compatibility problems with different blood types.

Experiment 1

The stability of five fluorocarbons was determined by measuring the strengths of their chemical bonds in kilocalories per mole (kcal/mol). The higher the average bond strength, the more stable the compound. The results are in Table 1.


Experiment 2

The amount of O2 or CO2 gas that dissolves in each fluorocarbon was measured by weighing out 100 g each of Fluorocarbons A-E, bubbling the O2 or CO2 through the fluorocarbon for one hour, and determining the mass of the resulting solution. The results are in Table 2.


Experiment 3

The time the body takes to decompose and eliminate the blood substitute was studied by measuring the amount of fluorine present in urine. The chemist found that, for each of Fluorocarbons A-E, the fluorine level rose to a maximum and then declined over a period of several days.
questions.question: 35. The chemist discovered a new, nonpoisonous fluorocarbon. It was a liquid that dissolved oxygen well. It was not eliminated quickly by the body and was stable only between the temperatures of 20°C and 35°C. Is this compound a potential blood substitute?

choices.A: Yes, because it is nonpoisonous.
choices.B: Yes, because it is retained by the body.
choices.C: No, because it is not stable at body temperature.
choices.D: No, because it does not dissolve carbon dioxide very well.

questions.question: 36. Which of the following graphs best illustrates the results of Experiment 3?

questions.question: 37. Why are only C—C and C—F bond strengths reported by the chemist?

choices.A: Because those bonds are hardest to break
choices.B: Because all other bonds are too weak to have their strengths measured
choices.C: Because only these bonds react with each other while the compound is in the body
choices.D: Because fluorocarbons only have bonds involving carbon and fluorine

questions.article:

Experiment 1

The stability of five fluorocarbons was determined by measuring the strengths of their chemical bonds in kilo-calories per mole (kcal/mol). The higher the average bond strength, the more stable the compound. The results are in Table 1.


Experiment 2

The amount of O2 or CO2 gas that dissolves in each fluorocarbon was measured by weighing out 100 g each of Fluorocarbons A-E, bubbling the O2 or CO2 through the fluorocarbon for one hour, and determining the mass of the resulting solution. The results are in Table 2.

questions.question: 38. Which of the following statements about the amounts of O2 and CO2 that dissolved in Fluorocarbons A-E is best supported by the results of Experiment 2？

choices.A: More O2 dissolved than CO2 in each of Fluorocarbons A-E.
choices.B: The lowest amount of O2 and CO2 gas dissolved in Fluorocarbon D.
choices.C: Temperature has no effect on the amount of CO2 that dissolves in Fluorocarbon E.
choices.D: The greater the amount of O2 dissolved, the faster the fluorocarbon was decomposed by the body.

questions.question: 39. Which of the following new compounds could NOT be one of the potential blood substitutes tested in these experiments?

choices.A: C2F5(CF2CF2)CF3
choices.B: (CF3)2CF(CF2CF2)CF3

questions.article:

questions.question: 40. Based on Experiment 2, which of Fluorocarbons A-E would be considered the best for transporting oxygen from the lungs to the tissues?

choices.A: Fluorocarbon A
choices.B: Fluorocarbon B
choices.C: Fluorocarbon C
choices.D: Fluorocarbon D
